results.title: A roof over your head; Detective work in the woods
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dandelion = Pusteblume”.
Two episodes of the successful children’s series Pusteblume. “A roof over your head” - People live in houses in order to protect themselves from the wind, rain, heat or cold. Peter Lustig experiences what can happen without a roof over one’s head. In addition, he shows us how people build new houses and how some animals build themselves a hideaway. “Tracks in the wood” - Peter Lustig finds lots of tracks made in the wood by animals who live there. Naturally, he also hears lots of different noises made by animals when they forage for food or creep through the undergrowth. People go into the woods too of course, to collect mushrooms or just to go for a walk. The forest ranger is really cross with those who rubbish the woods and damage the natural environment.

results.title: Foreigners
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
One of a series of films that examines the history of immigration to Australia. In this film, “White Australians” give their opinions on the migrant influx, while Irish, Chinese, English and Turkish migrants relate instances of intolerance in Australia. They refer to situations of race, language or cultural difference and of economic pressure. In this film, social commentator Phillip Adams, academic Dinny O’Hearn and (former) RSL President Bruce Ruxton also make comments on matters relating to national identity.

results.title: Dandelion = Pusteblume
results.brief_description: A highly successful children’s series which was broadcast by the second German TV Channel. Peter Lustig, the protagonist in each episode deals with a new topic each time and provides an informative, educational insight into the subject with, of course, a funny and entertaining story running through it.

results.title: The Golden land: 1840s-1900
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
This film examines the period of Australian history, 1840-1900, that included the Gold-rush years and the farming boom.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: The White Australia Policy
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Provides a history of Australian working attitudes to non European migration from the first entry restrictions on Chinese in 1885 to the acceptance of Indo-Chinese refugees in the 1970s. This film partoicularly looks at the “White Australia Policy”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Widening net 1945-
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Covers the period from 1945 to 1985. Shows how the enormous intake of migrants from Britain, Western Europe and the ;Mediterranean alter the face of Australia; and notes how from the early 1970’s, with a changing economy, recruitment fluctuates and then dies down. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: You keep juggling
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
One of a series of films that examines the history of immigration to Australia. This film discusses the assimilation of different cultures. Migrants speak of their experience as young people assimilation in Australia. For many there has been the conflict of finding a balance of identity between their parent’s home country values and Australian values.

results.title: Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers
results.brief_description: Famous Australian dancers and choreographers give lively and engaging interviews of their fascinating lives in the world of dance. Discover what it was like to be a dancer or choreographer in Australia during the past fifty years.
results.title_for_label: Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers

results.title: Sir Robert Helpmann
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Sir Robert Helpmann trained with the legendary ballerina Anna Pavlova and had a successful career in musical comedy in Australia before travelling to England where he became a star of both the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet” and the “Old Vic.”. Helpmann remembers his association with Ninette de Valois and his first meeting with Margot Fonteyn, the beginning of a twenty-seven year partnership. Helpmann combined his successful international career in ballet, theatre and film with his commitment to the development of the “Australian Ballet”. He discusses the background to his ballet, “The Display” and his collaboration with Rudolf Nureyev on the film of “Don Quixote”. As a dancer, choreographer, actor and director Sir Robert Helpmann has made a unique contribution to the performing arts in Australia.
